article: Sometimes things happen beyond expectation. A 10-year-old boy decided to study Judo  _  he had lost his left arm in a car accident. He began his  _  with an old Japanese Judo teacher. He was doing well, but he could not  _  why the teacher had taught him only one move for quite a long time. "Sir," the boy finally said, "I think I should  _  more moves." "But this is the  _  move you will ever need to know," the master replied. Not quite understanding, the boy kept  _  . Several months later, the teacher  _  the boy to his first tournament .  _  himself, the boy easily won his first two matches. The third match proved to be more  _  . However, after some time, the opponent became impatient. The boy used his one move to  _  the match. Now the boy was in the finals. This time, his opponent was bigger, stronger and more  _  . Concerned that the boy might get  _  , the referee wanted to stop the match. "No," the teacher  _  , "let him continue." Soon his opponent made a mistake.  _  the boy used his move to attack him. The boy won the match and became the champion. On the way home, the boy and the teacher  _  every move in every match. Then the boy asked  _  was really on his mind. "How did I win the tournament  _  only one move?" "You won for two reasons," the teacher answered. "First, you've  _  one of the most difficult moves in Judo. And second, the only known  _  for that move is to grasp your left arm. But you've lost it." The boy's biggest  _  had become his biggest strength.
